title: 115_hr250
content: The "Judicial Administration and Improvement Act of 2016" defines the former ninth circuit, new ninth circuit, and twelfth circuit. It also addresses the number and composition of circuits. The "Judicial Administration and Improvement Act of 2016" amends the number and composition of circuits in the United States Code, changing the ninth circuit to include California, Hawaii, Oregon, Washington, Guam, and Northern Mariana Islands, and creating a new twelfth circuit with Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, and Nevada. SEC. 4 amends the table in title 28, United States Code, by changing the ninth circuit to 21 judges and adding a new twelfth circuit with 8 judges. SEC. 5 adds Las Vegas, Phoenix, Anchorage, and Missoula to the twelfth circuit. SEC. 6 addresses the election of assignment of circuit judges. Each circuit judge of the former ninth circuit in active service will be reassigned to the new ninth or twelfth circuit based on their location. Circuit judges in certain states can elect to be permanently assigned to the new ninth circuit. Vacancies in positions will be addressed accordingly. After the reassignment of circuit judges from the former ninth circuit based on their location, vacancies in positions will be filled by the President for the twelfth circuit without regard to individual elections. SEC. 7. Senior judges from specific states can choose to be assigned to the new ninth or twelfth circuit. SEC. 8. Temporary judgeships are authorized. SEC. 8. Authorization of temporary judgeships for the twelfth circuit, with an additional circuit judge appointed for each circuit judge in regular active service who elects to be assigned to the new ninth circuit. Vacancies in the twelfth circuit will not be filled for each new appointment. SEC. 9. SENIORITY OF JUDGES. The seniority of judges assigned to the twelfth or new ninth circuit shall run from their commission date in the former ninth circuit. Temporary twelfth circuit judges' seniority starts from their commission date in the twelfth circuit. SEC. 10. APPLICATION TO CASES. The Act specifies procedures for cases pending in the former ninth circuit before the effective date of the Act. If a matter has been submitted for decision, further proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. If the matter has not been submitted, it will be transferred to the appropriate court and further proceedings will follow accordingly. If a petition for rehearing en banc is pending on or after the effective date of this Act, it will be considered by the court of appeals as if the Act had been in full force and effect when the appeal was filed. SEC. 11. ADMINISTRATION. The court of appeals for the ninth circuit may take administrative action to carry out this Act and its amendments. The court described shall cease to exist for administrative purposes 2 years after the effective date of this Act. SEC. 12. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 1 year after enactment. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums are authorized to be appropriated as necessary to carry out this Act and its amendments, including providing space and facilities for any new judicial positions.
